awd_abstract_narration:
NON-TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The objective of this REU Site is to train a diverse group of early undergraduate students in the interdisciplinary skills necessary to employ a data-driven approach to materials design. REU students are learning to use advanced data analytics, such as machine learning and artificial intelligence, to efficiently identify trends in materials properties that can be used to predict the characteristics of undiscovered materials. This relatively new materials informatics approach promises to enhance efficiency and productivity, but also requires specialized training. This Site provides a comprehensive summer training experience that includes: introductory cross-training in data and materials science fundamentals, hands-on research training, formal educational seminars, and workshops. The Site focuses on providing these opportunities to students that typically do not have exposure to extensive scientific resources. All participants are prepared for careers in materials science in industry, academia, and national laboratories through customized professional development and networking opportunities in addition to extensive support and guidance. 

TECHNICAL DESCRIPTION: The increasing reliance on big data to guide innovation necessitates a change in the way that materials science students are trained. It has become essential for students to have experience in data-driven approaches and familiarity with the techniques that are now common to the field, yet these opportunities are very limited for undergraduates. This Site represents an entry point into this new approach to training, and prepares students for the emerging field of materials informatics. Training will include an introduction to essential topics such as material science applications, an introduction to data driven approaches, an introduction to machine learning with Python, and laboratory skill and safety training. All research topics are inherently interdisciplinary since the students are paired with primary and secondary mentors that specialize in different approaches to materials science. Scientific topics explored by the students can be divided into four categories, each with an inherent materials informatics component: (1) materials discovery and design; (2) high-throughput exploration; (3) quantitative structure–property relations; and (4) exploring and linking length scales. Taken together, these topics address a societal need for significant acceleration of new materials design and discovery, emergent properties and processing strategies. Reducing the cost and time it takes to discover and develop new materials and technologies can positively impact our economy, our environment, and our future.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The REU Site: Data-driven Materials Design at the University at Buffalo offered ten-week research opportunities to 26 undergraduates over three summers (2020-2023; the program skipped 2019 due to the COVID-19 pandemic). These students came from 11 different states across the U.S. About 40% of them attended schools with limited research opportunities, making this program their first chance to experience scientific research before deciding whether to pursue graduate school. More than half (57%) of the participants belong to groups traditionally underrepresented in the sciences, and 50% are women. The students received a stipend, as well as housing and travel expenses to and from Buffalo, except in 2020 when the program was conducted virtually.

Each student conducted research under the guidance of a faculty mentor, exploring a variety of topics in materials science. These projects included predicting the electrochemical properties of 2D materials, creating a database for PFAS adsorption descriptors, applying large language models to battery literature, and studying thin films for magnetic memory applications. These were genuine research endeavors, meaning the outcomes were unknown beforehand and the students experienced both the excitement and challenges of research, including moments when things didn't go as planned. Despite the short ten-week period, all students contributed to their research groups and presented their findings at a scientific forum. Some even co-authored articles published in peer-reviewed journals.

Mentoring played a crucial role in the REU program. During orientation, students completed formal online training on the responsible and ethical conduct of research, covering topics like authorship, collaborative research, conflicts of interest, human subjects, and research misconduct. Throughout the program, students received mentorship from faculty, research mentors, near-peer mentors, and through group mentoring sessions. In addition to research, the program provided various professional development opportunities, seminars, and team-building exercises. Each week, there were one or two professional development activities, including workshops on preparing and presenting scientific results, applying to graduate school, career seminars, and community service events.

At the end of the program, all participants gave a 15-minute presentation to the department. They also presented posters on their research at a school-wide summer research symposium. In addition to a poster, one department-level presentation was selected to represent the REU as an oral presentation at the school-wide symposium. Remarkably, in just ten weeks, students progressed from knowing little about their research area to delivering talks and presenting posters. Despite the hard work, all participants reported that their interest in materials and data science had either increased or remained high.

One of the program's goals is to encourage students to continue their education in science and engineering. Of the nine students who had graduated by May 2023, eight had moved into technical fields such as graduate school, engineering, research, or data analysis. The status of the ninth graduate is unknown, while the remaining 17 students are still working towards their undergraduate degrees.
